response.answer_text: After reading over all these answers I guess I am abnormal. The only class I got a B+ in was French, but this didn’t stop me from passing the French philosophy baccalaureate after high school. I started getting straight As in junior high and I don’t remembering studying very hard (but I don’t remember doing anything else either). My primary “strategy” was to be curious about what my classes would be in the future. I studied algebra in library books before entering 6th grade. I asked my teacher if we would be studying algebra that year. She just smiled and shook her head, not saying a word. I have no idea what she was thinking, but I continued studying algebra on my own, so when I did Algebra 1 and 2 in 7th and 9th grade, I got A’s and continued to get As in math throughout high school. So learn how to learn on your own and you will be able to keep learning the rest of your life! My second strategy (according to what is written in yearbooks) was to spend much of my study time explaining the material to classmates. You need to learn the material well to be able to answer questions that you hadn’t thought to ask. This is the first advice given to law students, form study groups! Don’t sit there by yourself wondering for hours why the first derivative of a logarithmic function involves an inverse. The problem then becomes who to ask to be in your study group. In law school you are required to do 8 hours of studying per day, every day, plus classes, and social drinking (aka networking). This is to push you to your limits: Will you be able to work to deadline for 168 hours (in a week) sleeping in naps and drinking kefir to stop your stomach from growling? So you divide up your subjects and one or two people focus on contracts, property, civil procedure etc. Unfortunately there are freeloaders who focus on networking and don’t spend time figuring out the significance of the Fountainbleau case. Instead, in high school have a study group for each class. The primary purpose is for you to learn the material, so if someone in your study group doesn’t keep up, don’t worry about it: just work harder. Bottom line (1) be curious and learn how to teach yourself and (2) be cooperative with your classmates. You are not competing with them, you are competing with every high school student in the world. Teams of teens are always more supportive than one teen!

In high school, your grades serve one purpose: to get you into college. Because of this, GPA is extremely important because it can help in the admissions process to your top colleges and also when applying to scholarships. Having just applied to a bunch of colleges and scholarships as a senior in high school, I have seen first hand how useful they can be. But, also from experience, grades aren’t everything. I had a weighted GPA of 4.2 on a 4.0 scale, which isn’t too bad, and just short of a perfect score on the ACT, but I still didn’t make it into more than half of the schools I applied to (of course, most of the schools I applied to were highly selective schools with acceptance rates of about 10–15%). But I digress. The reason I wanted to mention that is that you certainly want to do everything just to look good. That’s a bad idea. Instead, you want to participate in and do well in activities and classes that you actually enjoy. So, first I suggest is that you try and balance the two, preferably with the high level courses in your strongest subjects. Don't try to be completely well-rounded. That doesn't make you special, contrary to what everyone else might say. You certainly want spikes, with certain areas demonstrating having a much stronger area. You kinda want to learn to be the math kid, the science kid, the history kid, the drama kid, the athlete, etc. Choose one an just be the best at it. Now, I'm not saying that you should just give up in all other areas. But I'm certainly not advocating that you try to be the best at everything. It's counterproductive. You end up losing a lot of time, building up a lot of stress, and never reaching a solid aptitude in any particular field. So now that you've gone on to balancing out your courseload, do the same with your extracurriculars. Don't overload yourself with after-school activities. Choose a few activities where you really devote your time and move up the ladder. Everyone would prefer to see that you were in one or two clubs but as the president of those clubs rather than merely members of 10 clubs. Finding a good balance in your extracurriculars will also enable you to find time for homework and anything else that maters in your life. Unless you are just a naturally gifted student, especially one with a photographic memory, getting straight A's will be difficult, but nowhere near impossible. It merely takes a lot of work and commitment. The first step is obvious. Study. Find other students in your class who may be at a similar or higher level than you in the class, maybe some people who are already getting straight A's. Even if you can't meet up with them all the time to study, you can certainly have them show you a few different studying methods. Maybe you'll like one of them. And when it comes to homework, unless it's a big assignment, don't place to much effort into it. I know, you're probably screaming, "What?" But trust me, half the time, the homework assigned turns out to be busy work. I think that completing these assignments quickly and efficiently can allow for actual studying while at least indicating whether you know the material or not. But ALWAYS do the homework. Most times it's a busy work, but as I said before, it can indicate how. I have of the material you know. And a lot of times, the homework will be worth free points. Now, the second point is that you must develop relationships with your teachers. It's absolutely essential. They can be a lot of help one-on- one when the material doesn't make sense and they can certainly offer help in other classes and provide great recommendation letters. Third of all, you want to find the perfect place to study, and bring along the proper tools. Notecards, notebooks, textbooks, pens, pencils, and highlighters. And create a system for note-taking. You want to find a way that you can write the information down somewhere because it will help you retain the information better, but you want to do it in a way that is quick enough so that you don’t waste too much time writing everything down. And please choose a place without distractions. It can be so hard to not get distracted sometimes. So I usually advise that students go to libraries to study. Why? Because the library is generally a quiet place to stay, with internet and computers if needed, and you’re always surrounded by books. And it’s also a great place to meet up with friends and go study together. All in all, getting straight A's can be easy. But if you want some difficulty in your classes and want to show colleges and employers that you are motivated, you want to take the more difficult classes. Good grades depends on balances within your schedule and setting up relationships. You need to learn to study, and it's very important to find your learning style early on. And you need to stay motivated. Don't get hit by any senioritis early on. Remember that you're responsible for your own education. Don't lose easy points for homework, and use your resources to do well on tests. Always, ALWAYS study. You can't expect to do well if you don't put in the work. Just follow these steps, and you're sure to be on the path to straight A's. You'll be able to refine this plan once you find your own rhythm and system. Good luck! You got this!

So you want straight A’s, huh? Well here’s how you do it, coming from a guy who’s only been a straight-A student for a single semester in his life and spent the rest of the time messing around. Let’s get started. Get ready to say goodbye to your social life because holy shit you will have little to no spare time This is the entire reason I abandoned my pursuit of good grades in the first place. It’s so time-consuming and stressful. You’ll have to alienate all your friends when they invite you out and you have to say “Sorry no I have to study” so many times they think you hate them. If you’re responsible in high school you’ll be juggling a hell of a lot. Let’s say you’re taking a full plate of classes, you play a sport, you’ve got a part-time job and you hang out with your friends. You’ll probably get no sleep and explode from exhaustion at some time throughout this shit. So prioritise. If you asked this question then I assume you’ve chosen to prioritise your grades over several other things in teenage life. So my advice is hold off on getting a part-time joblimit your extracurriculars; you’ll be spending a lotta time studying and contrary to what everyone seems to think, being in a marching band won’t make universities like you betterdon’t go on super super time-wasting social events or events that have a really long recovery time e.g. binge drinking, drug benders, full-day hangouts. Limit it to the length of a movie. Or just see a movieNow for the studying thing. Find your favourite flavor of gum and load up on it. Chew that flavour in class, when studying, when researching and during tests/exams. Only chew it during academic activities. This is for two purposes. For one, chewing it only when studying will do some association thing where you start almost liking studying cause you like the gum. For two, chewing the same flavour every time will lead to better memory retention. Hence sticking to the same flavour.Get your typing speed up as high as you can possibly get itDon’t highlight. Highlighting don’t do shit and are for people who read things over twice cause they didn’t understand it the first time.Type out all the notes you get verbatim. That’s why you’ve gotta get your typing speed up, so it’s not too time-consuming.Typing out your notes, plus the gum, leads to maximum retention of everything. What sticks with you is usually most importantIf you insist on studying late at night and messing up your sleep schedule, No-Doz, Red Bull and Ritalin are your best friends. Both for the night and for waking up the next morning.Learn your school’s referencing system off by heart so you can cite your sources without having to google how to do it every timeGood luck, y’all. Hopefully your pursuit of academic excellence is successful. I personally don’t think it’s worth it, but then again I’m the same guy to nearly kill himself from binge drinking and get a Venn Diagram tattooed on his wrist, so don’t listen to me.

For one thing, many students who enter high school find it to be a very different game than what they had experienced before then. They are suddenly thrown into an environment where the academic level is more challenging, the teachers are more demanding, and - most of all - there is suddenly far more competition for the top grades. Everyone knows that K-8 is all just preparatory, and while you need to do well, your future is not going to be determined by whether you get an A or a B or even an occasional C in any particular subject. When you get to high school, however, the brighter kids who have always assumed (and their parents expected) would be college bound quickly realize that now things are different, now the grades do matter, and a single non-A grade in just one class could make the difference between whether or not they get into the college of their dreams. Thus, the really serious and motivated students step it up big time, and quickly, and leave the other students - which, unfortunately, includes you at the moment - in their dust. Just to warn you, this whole phenomenon will repeat at an even greater level of intensity when you start college. Fortunately, it is not too late for you to make some changes and salvage your high school experience. It sounds like you have already damaged your GPA, and so class valedictorian is probably beyond reach for you - and maybe some of the most selective colleges as well. Nevertheless, there is still time for you to step it up, finish strong, and position yourself to have some good college options. Even with your best effort, though, you might not make straight As. This depends to some extent on your competition. If you are attending a school with a lot of very bright kids, you might still get beat out for the top grades in some courses. A lot depends on the teacher: some will reward top grades to all who earn them, no matter how many that may be. Others may “grade on the curve” - either by personal conviction or because they were ordered to do so. I would suggest just resolving to do your personal best and not worry about the competition or how your grades compare to theirs. Doing A-worthy work in high school does require quite a step up from middle school. There will be a further step up when you get to college, or when you take AP or dual-enrollment courses. The general rule of thumb is two hours of study for every hour of class in high school and a 3:1 ratio for college-level classes. Of course these are just rules of thumb, and the actual amount of time needed will vary somewhat depending upon the student and the course. In most cases, though, the difference is in the direction of more, and not less, time being needed. It is pretty clear that most high school students don’t come any where close to this 2:1 ratio, and quite a few college-level students aren’t hitting 3:1 either. Simply blocking out enough study time in your schedule to make sure you are hitting these ratios will go far toward assuring that you are at least in pack and will be competitive. Time alone won’t be enough, though. You also have to study smart. Give yourself breaks, get plenty of sleep and exercise, and eat right to keep your brain at its peak. Set up a good study area, organize your notes and materials, and ruthlessly eliminate all distractions. You need to put intensive effort into your studying; quality, not quantity, is the key.

I’m a straight A student myself and honestly people definitely exaggerate when they say you will have no social life if you want straight A’s. Of course some people need to give up on their social life in order to have time to study but I myself for example never have to do that. I graduated high school (well, secondary school since I’m not in America) this year and never studied more than like 5 hours a day. Most of the times I studied half an hour and then got distracted for around 15 minutes and then started again. Sometimes I didn’t get distracted and it was easier to memorize it all but things like getting distracted and having struggle to memorize is something everybody experiences. But getting A’s is not the most difficult thing in the world. It’s really just about how you study. If you know how to study efficiently you won’t need to give up on anything you’re doing tbh. You just need to find out the studying method that works best for you, start off early enough and repeat your stuff and of course take enough breaks or else you will actually go insane. I actually made a video where I talk a bit more about that, so if you want to check it out, here you go:

Build good habits, especially sleep. This is quite possibly the most important. Not only should you work to develop studying and work habits, but even simple habits like washing your face every morning, cleaning your room, tidying your desk, not checking your phone often, clearing your email etc. When tasks like those become habit, it’s much easier to focus on your larger goals. Sleep is the number one habit you should work on. While it’s near impossible to get 8 hours of sleep on a school night (for me anyways, I wake up at 6AM), you should always have a goal of at least 7 hours. Now it may seem hard at first going to bed earlier AND doing everything you need to do, but trust me its worth it. When you’re in class you’ll be able to focus better and you’ll retain a lot of the information, which means you don’t have to study as much. Plus, you’ll come off as a nicer person in general. Building habits is not easy. There’s different methods that work for each person. Personally, I used apps on my phone. Productive and SleepTown worked best. Productive was great for tracking any habit I wanted and SleepTown was great for forcing me to go to bed and wake up on time by restricting my phone access. I was essentially parenting myself. But find whatever works for you, sometimes apps aren’t that useful. Learn to beat procrastination through willpower, not motivation. You’ll hear a lot about motivation. But the hard truth is, you’re never going to WANT to do your math homework. Motivation is simply the reason why you are about to do an action. What you need is willpower, and here’s why: Procrastination is not just a human thing. It’s an animal thing. For example, when two hyenas meet at the border of their territories, both dogs will proceed to dig a hole in the ground. This is because the hyena is confused if they should cross the border to protect their territory or respect the boundary and walk away. There is a conflict of instinct, so the hyena therefore does neither option until the other hyena makes a move. When you have a project due in a few days, you feel a pressure to start the project because you know you want to avoid doing it the night before. But at the same time, you also want to avoid doing the project at that moment, because you’re tired and it’s not an activity that you enjoy or benefit from directly. So of course you do neither and stare at your phone for three hours. You are conflicted between wanting the thing to be done, but not wanting to do it. You can overcome this through WILLPOWER! Not motivation. Willpower, in this case, is the ability to overcome instinct and conflict. Obviously, the assignment can’t be done without you doing it, so you have to push through. Usually this “push” comes when it’s the night before and you panic, commonly known as the procrastination tipping point, but you want to avoid that. Willpower is like a muscle. And like any muscle, you can strengthen it through exercise. I used chores as my exercise. For example, one morning I randomly took all of my clean laundry that I hadn’t put away and dumped it all over my bed, forcing me to put it away. You can use any progression of small tasks to build your willpower. This is how some people seem to just get home and immediately start their homework! Prioritize and organize Not only should you write a to-do list, but write it in a very specific order. Whatever work is due directly the next day, do that first. It’ll take it off your shoulders. Start with something easy, like a quick worksheet (I usually start with chemistry because I find it easy). Use it like a “warm-up” the same way you would for a workout. Also include a cool down like vocabulary studying. Put the large projects and assignments in the middle. You can come up with your own system, but this is what I suggest. Learn to focus Focus is another muscle that needs exercise. The ability to get “in the zone” and work for hours on end is extremely useful, especially when the environment in which you’re working is not quiet or peaceful. I used the app Forest, in which you plant a tree for a set amount of time, and during that time period you can’t use your phone or else the tree dies. I also listen to lo-fi hip hop/jazz with headphones in to block out any other noise. Both of these things help me focus purely on what I’m doing. Meditation can also help, especially mindfulness. While I can’t speak from experience, I know many people find this useful as they develop the ability to block out distracting thoughts while they work. Work faster and smarter Sometimes studying for 45 min is just as effective (if not MORE effective) than studying 3 hours. The length of time does not matter as much as the material you cover and how you cover it. As said before, everyone has different methods that work for them, but here are my main tips: Use Quizlet for vocabulary. If you haven’t used it before, start using it now!Study for math or any similar subjects using practice problems. Ask your teacher for extra practice or look something up.Use online videos like Khan Academy and Crash Course to do a quick review if you’re in a pinch. While your notes and textbook are the best source, these videos help when you only have about 15 minutes.For humanities subjects (especially history or government) draw flowcharts and other visual representations of knowledge. It’ll help you draw connections between all of the things you’re learning. It’s easier to remember one multi-faceted concept than multiple simple topics.As you’ve probably heard before, don’t study all the night before. When you’re given a new vocabulary list for a language, make a Quizlet right away! Start learning right away! You know there’s going to be a quiz eventually. Prepare for the inevitable, because often times teachers don’t announce things early enough.There’s other ways to work faster, and most of it comes from practice. I can type very fast and I tend to work at a VERY fast pace which gives me a huge advantage. I developed this speed by using my summer homework (which I get a lot of) as “training,” setting a timer and seeing how much I could finish before the timer was up (while still submitting quality work!) It’s tough and there’s a limit, but keep trying. (Also can you see my theme of treating school like athletics? Oddly enough I’m not an athlete…) Finally, learn when to give up. You can’t win every battle. Sometimes, you’ll bomb a quiz you studied really hard for. Sometimes you’ll get home too late and you can’t finish your homework. Sometimes you just don’t get it and the extra help isn’t working. Sometimes you’ll stare blankly at the paper and feel like you’re brain dead. It’s okay to fail. It’s not the end of the world. Just keep trying. Remember to take breaks. I never do homework on Fridays. Ever. I never stay up past 10PM, not even for homework (unless it’s a group project and I’d ruin other people’s grades). Sometimes I say “screw it” and just nap the whole afternoon. I still get As though! Take care of yourself, take mental health days if you need it, see your counselor if you need it, talk to who you need to talk to. Don’t ever prioritize school over your mental health. It’s just not worth it. For context: I’m a straight-A student in a magnet program in which I take highly advanced humanities courses (plus STEM stuff if I want to). I take piano lessons, I’m in choir, and participate in stage crew. I get home around 5:30 each night. I’ve been in a magnet program since 6th grade.

You've not given much information. Consider that you went to a physician's office and said, "Last year I felt fairly well but this year I don't feel at all well. What should I do, Doctor?" A doctor would then begin to ask questions among them - are you doing anything differently this year than last year? To which question one could give many answers like - this year I only sleep two to three hours a night. With that kind of answer, Doctor would get an idea of why you don't feel well this year and prescribe more sleep and possibly something to help you sleep. What 's different about this year than last? It's quite remarkable for an A/B student to become a D/F student - that's not an accident, that doesn't just happen. 10th grade may be more difficult than 9th but there's not enough difference between 9th and 10th grade curriculum to doom A/B students to Ds and Fs. And your skills were strong enough in 9th grade to warrant As and Bs - the answer does not lie in your skills. Skills don't slide downhill between 9th and 10th grade. If you were a capable reader and writer last year, you still have those skills this year. So what is different? Is your attendance at school still regular? Are you in school most days? Prior to your panic attacks - were you paying reasonable attention in class? Have you been handing in homework and on time? Are your homework grades decent grades or are your homework and test grades both spiraling down? Do you have a history of panic attacks prior to this year? Your Ds and Fs this year are not the problem - they're a symptom of the problem. To answer your question, more information is needed but even without it it's safe to say - you could get on top of this. A/B students can return to being A/B students.

It depends: What kind of straight A student do you want to be? There are two types: Easily made A’s and slightly more challenging but still pretty easily made straight A’s. Easily made A’s To achieve this level of straight A’s, take on-level classes where no studying is required. Attend class, and pay attention. That's it. That’s all you have to do. Slightly more challenging but still pretty easily made straight A’s To achieve this level of straight A’s, take all AP or honors classes. Expect to have projects, homework, and a tad bit of studying. However, here's the key here: it is not difficult. There is more work and it is slightly more challenging, but as long as you apply yourself with the mentality that you can succeed, you will. If you wrap your mind around the fact that these classes aren't really more difficult than the on-level ones; rather, there is more work and it is in greater depth, you're going to have your A’s. This is the most important thing about high school that academically inclined kids need to remember: straight A’s don’t matter. A B is fine every now and then. The important part is understanding the material, retaining it, and knowing how to apply it later on. I made a 98 in Algebra II, because I wanted an A. My problem was that I wasn't truly learning the information. I was retaining it for as long as I needed it for my A and then it was gone. That was two years ago, and as I type this, I've not the slightest clue how to do Algebra II. I'm not dumber than I was, but I didn't let the material become a part of me, and now I couldn't recall how to do those problems to save my life. TL;DR: A’s are cool, but understanding and retention are cooler. Don't get so caught up in straight A’s that you forget to learn something.

Study smart, not hard. This might seem like a cliche line which probably every revision Youtuber says, but it's actually true. If you want to improve your grades shift to a goal-oriented study rather than a time-oriented study. You may see your peers boasting about the hours they have put in studying Physics or studying and creating notes on Psychology, while you just feel how unproductive you have been. But in fact, all they have done is waste hours of time and energy on a thing which might have taken much less time than they think. What is a goal-oriented study? Studying through goals. Each day you write down your aims and you complete it. Show dedication towards your goals. Don’t sleep without completing it. In the long run, you will notice how sometimes you are able to study longer hours without even realizing it! In the time-oriented study, you tend to set an unrealistic hour of study and create a mental block that after this I will no longer be able to be productive. For example, say you thought that today I will study for 8 hours, you open a book and you start studying, after some time you check the watch 1 hour has passed you think damn 6 hours worth of study left, a mental block is created because “6 hours” is a big figure, you start feeling lethargic and you get distracted, some think that we 6 hours left, I can do it after some time, and thus you end up being unproductive. In the goal-oriented study, you know that you have one whole day, you have to complete your goals so that you can go on and accomplish new goals tomorrow. If you start following this, you will read ahead of classes, understand much more than your peers, and complete your syllabus much before the examination, which will give you time to revise thoroughly using the very same method. Dedication and discipline will help a lot in getting the most out of this technique. If you pair this up with a good note-taking method it can get much more effective!

Here are the three methods ways that come to my mind: Learn how to learn. This is the obvious one that everyone points out. Learn how to be more efficient with your studying. If you get a bad grade on a test, figure out what you can adjust when studying for the next one. Create methods for note taking and stay organized. Review consistently throughout the school year, and always think about how you can improve.Take easier classes. Going into high school, I took three honors courses and stuck on the honors/AP tracks throughout high school. My grades suffered as a result. I also have friends that did not take the honors/AP route and study less while getting better grades and a superior GPA. Think about this a lot first, because it’s harder to enter an honors/AP track later on than it is to drop.Take classes you enjoy. It’s a lot easier to get better grades in a class when one actually likes the subject material.HOWEVER, consider why you want straight A’s in the first place. While it looks nice on transcripts, it’s really not that important. I can understand if you want straight A’s to show colleges, because I’m going through the application process right now, but in 10 years, will anyone really care whether you got an A or B in any of your classes? Will you care? Chances are, that’s a hard no. Challenging yourself and learning as much as you can is far more important to your personal development and career than a letter on paper ever will.

From my experience of being in high school, I have developed a few habits that have helped me thus far. Now, I don’t know exactly who you are, what you excel at, or how well you are currently doing in school at this moment, but I have three important tips that can truly enhance your experience and help boost your grade up to reach a 4.0 (or higher) GPA. Motivation and Focus. Although many people would like great grades and excellent test scores, they find it daunting to actually study hard and work for it. Hence, motivation comes in. If you truly want to get an A in your class, you have to study for it. You don’t have to study like a maniac nor do you have to cut time off with your friends/family just because of the Biology Exam you have in a day or two. Find time to study, before or after school. Do you spend some extra time before school, having nothing to do or no where to go? Go over your notes and annotate/highlight them through, rereading the concepts you understand and emphasizing the areas that you may be weakest at. It is difficult at times to comprehend various different concepts at the same time and it may seem overwhelming, and that’s alright, it’s a natural feeling many students know well. I feel that way frequently in my Chemistry class. You have online resources (Khan Academy being one of the best) that will help you. If you put your mind to it, you will achieve great things, I can assure you that. If you put in the effort, it will bear fruit.Organization and Time Management. I cannot stress how important being organized is, especially in high school and especially if your juggling through numerous AP classes or Honors classes. If you can invest in a cheap planner/calendar to keep your notes in, please do. Write down important dates (exam dates, pop quizzes, assignment due dates, etc…) and manage your time well to not only study for the tests but to get your needed assignments finished on time and with great effort. Do not slack off to the last minute. Most teachers will know and realize if you wrote this up in the period before. Do not risk getting a docked grade because you forget an assignment date, either. Write everything down, it helps tremendously.If You’ve Studied But Still Don’t Get It, Ask Your Teacher or a Tutor. My mom always tells me that it’s better to ask questions, no matter how stupid they seem, than to sit there in silence and get no answers. If you have any questions, write them down and ask your teacher perhaps after class or after school. If your teacher can’t help, then find a tutor who is willing to help as well. Teachers ( at least most of them ) are willing to help you if you are willing to seek help. There’s no shame in asking for help if you truly don’t get what’s being asked of you.Personally, I have gone through my high schools years thus far getting straight A’s and good grades on my mid-terms and finals rather easily, but I realize that for other people, it may be difficult. I hope the above tips will help guide you in a similar direction and help give you the motivation that you need to strive for success. P.S. Please, don’t cheat your way through high school either. Not only does this guarantee a fail in the assignment/class/course, but it ruins your reputation for a substantial amount of time unless you are able to mend your mistakes, which is a difficult task to do. Be honest and humble when it comes to your work.

Getting straight A’s in High School can be difficult, but not impossible. I’ve said this before in a post: grades are not indicative of your intelligence but instead a sign of the hard work that you’ve put in. The reason A’s are so difficult to get for some is because it requires a good amount of time put in. Think of it like this, if you have a trip to China coming up in 1 year, but you only practice Chinese for half an hour once or twice a month, you really think you will be proficient in Chinese by the time your trip comes? Probably not. It’s the same with grades. You need to put in the time to show that you’ve mastered the material. My suggestion would be to manage your time wisely. There are a lot of courses you take in high school at once. Put in more study time for the courses that you find difficult and less into the ones you find easy. Also, ask questions. I feel like these answers miss an important aspect of the question. It's one thing to learn how to memorize content well, though that skill isn't particularly useful for anything other than passing tests. It's not helpful outside of school and undergraduate university. I was dux (top in academics) at my school 4 years ago (now about to finish an applied maths/engineering degree), and very little of my success was down to having a good memory. I'm pretty weak at this, to be honest. I always focused on being able to understand, and also derive, all of the key concepts in the class. If you can pull that off, then a nasty exam question (that you haven't practiced repeatedly) can't throw you off, because you have a good grasp of every tool that you might need to answer it, whatever the question might be. (If you're interested in an example of this approach, really getting to the bottom of a concept, then comment on this with a topic from school that you're pretty comfortable with, and I'll try apply it to that. Idk what age and year level you are, so its tricky to know what a good topic would be for the example :-)  ) The way you get to this level of understanding is to constantly apply what you've learned to the world you see around you. Come up with little theories, then test them against what you've been taught and see if they give you the answer you expect. If not, make a question from it, and talk to someone more knowledgeable about it, like a teacher. Explain what you do understand, and the bit that doesn't seem to make sense. You'll either find out that you were wrong, and improve your understanding, or occasionally find out that you're right, and that there's more to it than they explain at your level of school. I always loved that feeling, and the explanations of the extra bits were always pretty interesting too. All this has three advantages over a memory based approach: 1) it's more useful.  you learn more than you otherwise would, because you're asking tricky questions and testing your understanding. You can apply it in a variety of contexts, not just in a test, which means you'll be able to make better use of it in real life. 2) it's much less boring. Tests stop being big scary important hurdles that take a lot of mental energy to cram for, and become guides for where you should direct your curiosity. the grades come as a by product of your interest. Its much easier to find energy to study, since its something you genuinely enjoy. 3) you become a much better thinker this way. I know people who are much more capable book learners than me,  but their problem solving skills aren't as practiced. They're much more easily stumped by a new situation, less intuitive about handling new contexts, and less comfortable picking up new skills. And that there is the real point of high school: learning to get better at learning. The actual content, you'll probably have forgotten 80% of it by age 25. But being able to quickly become effective in a situation you haven't practiced before is the highest leverage skill a person can have, and will help you succeed with whatever you decide to attempt in life. They always find a way to get better at studying, looking for new studying strategies and making them better by applying them to their life. TIME. Learn how to manage your time, learn how to plan. Some people learn better by seeing, others by hearing, others by doing. Find out which one you are. Look on books or on the Internet on how the brain works, and try to find the best ways to memorize and understand concepts. After you’ve done these two things, search everywhere for studying strategies. Try them all, until you find the best ones for you.PAY ATTENTION AT SCHOOL. Pay attention during lessons. You’ll have 40% of your job already done.IF YOU DON’T LIKE A SUBJECT, MAKE IT INTERESTING. Look at subjects with a different perspective. I didn’t really like history because my teachers just wanted us to memorize dates of events, and that was all. But one day, before the school year started, I was looking at my history book with one of my friends, explaining to her that that year my class would have started studying from Alexander the Great. I looked at the page and there was a photo of a statue of him. And in that moment, I realised that he had actually been real. He had been a person, just like me, my friend, and everyone. I realised that history wasn’t about dates to memorize. It was about people. About what they had done, what they loved and hated, what they wanted, what they were afraid of. So I started seeing the subject differently. I still had to memorize the dates, but everytime we started something new, I had the chance to “meet” a new person. I started looking for info about those people. It was interesting to see how they thought, the causes and consequences of their actions. I started seeing History as something completely different: a chance to learn from the past. Here’s an example: you can learn skills by watching how others have done it. If you wanted to learn leadership skills, who would have been the best teachers if not Alexander the Great, Pericles, Caesar, Napoleon, Washington, Gandhi, etc? Learn from their mistakes and their victories. See it as a chance for yourself.GO BEYOND SCHOOL. When you’ve found what interests you about a subject, go beyond school work and research for yourself. Teachers will love it. Trust me, my history teacher was amazed by my interest for her subject.STAY CURIOUS. If there’s something outside schools subjects that interests you, find a little bit of time to learn about it. It will be useful. Here’s my example: I find criminology interesting, and I study it alone when I have time. But it has become incredibly useful: learning about drugs, poisons and killings has helped me both in History and Chemistry.BELIEVE IN YOURSELF. You should always believe in yourself. Here’s a little story of mine as an example. I used to hate Maths. And I still do. I was good, had some of the best grades in the class, but I wasn’t really “shining” like in the other subjects. Well, as I told you, I had my reasons: I hate Maths. But my teacher - who, by the way, is amazing, so a little bit of luck with teachers is always the best - always believed in me. He tried to convince my class to participate in two maths lectures for high schoolers held by a university. A girl and a boy from my class who are maths geniuses - especially the boy - participated, and I did as well. The girl is one of my best friends and I was the one who convinced her to go. We went and, of course, we understood nothing. They were speaking about concepts that we would have studied years later. However, I’ve always liked challgenes, especially with things I don’t like. So, out of the three, guess who was the one who kept writing notes down, even though she understood nothing. Yeah, me. I was a little bit curious, I have to admit it. One other time, there was a little maths contest between a lot of schools. You have to know that here in Italy high schools are very different. You study basic subjects like Maths, Italian, History, Latin in most high schools, but then it changes. There are the “Licei Classici”, where you study a lot more Latin + Ancient Greek, and where you don’t study sciences a lot, then there are the “Licei Scientifici”, where they study less Latin and concentrate on sciences. And others, but that doesn’t matter now. Of course, which ones do you think would perform better in a maths contest? You got it, the Licei Scientifici. Usually, you also have to prepare for this contests a few months in advance, together with your teacher and a group (they are group-based, about 10 people for every school). Well, our maths teacher had the great idea to ask as if we wanted to participate the day when they would have been held. He comes in the morning and says: “Yeah, well, there’s this maths contest this afternoon. Would you like to participate?” He had already asked me once to participate in an individual contest and I had said no, because, as I said, I hate maths, but that time I decided to say yes. He also asked two other girls of my class (not the one who is great in maths, though; she’s very silent and he seems like he forgets about her, but she couldn’t go anyway so it wasn’t that big of a problem) and other girls from the school. We went there with no hope whatsoever because we hadn’t prepared at all, since he had asked us that same morning. There were thirteen other schools, mostly Licei Scientifici. Well, we are a Liceo Classico. Basically, we were screwed. But we did it just for fun. The rules were simple: do something correctly, you get points. Do it wrong, points are taken away from you. Basically: don’t make mistakes. While all my group was desperately trying to solve some of the problems, most of the things we had never heard of, I tried to solve a problem that looked like it was okay. I thought I had got a solution, but I tried it other times to be sure. In the end, we decided to take the risk. I never really thought it was correct: I hated Maths, came from a Liceo Classico and hadn’t prepared at all, I had no chance at all. Well, my solution was correct. I couldn’t believe it. I still hated Maths, but knowing that I had got the correct result was a great feeling. And my group was so happy! That made me feel even better, because all of them were smiling. They had regained some hope. Of course, we weren’t able to solve the other problems and ended up 7th, but considering we hadn’t prepared and that most of the others were scientific schools, I was happy, especially considering my little victory. However, I’m the kind of person who never really talks about that. So when our teacher came to tell us that he was happy with our result, I just smiled and said nothing. Another girl started speaking about the correct solution which had given us some points, and another group from my school (but the girls were older than us) was there too. So the teacher asked her if it was her who had solved the problem, and she pointed at me. He looked at me with a look that was just saying: “See? I told you”. Yeah, well, I started looking at Maths with a different perspective. At the end of the year, me and my other best friend who is great at maths were the only ones in the class having 10 (A) in Maths, which made me kind of proud of myself. So never doubt yourself. But, even though I love the challenge, I have to admit that I still don’t really like the subject.

Achieving straight A's in high school is just a question of strategy and discipline. Here's a quick roundup: 1) At the macro-cosmic level, I suggest that you take a close look at the larger scheme of things in your life. That is, sit down to explore and establish compelling, inspiring and overarching long-range goals, broken down into short-term, medium-term, and long-term perspectives, as follows: - what I want to BE; - what I want to DO; - what I want to HAVE; - what I want to IMPROVE; - what I want to CHANGE; and also considering the following major life dimensions in your life: - academic pursuit (as your top priority); - mental development; - career aspirations; - physical health; - financial wealth; - family relationships; - social networking; - recreational ventures (including hobbies, interests, sports, vacations, etc.); - spiritual development (including contributions to society, volunteering, etc.); Upon completion of reflection, contemplation and introspection, the next logical step for you is to work out a systematic game plan, whereby you need to translate all your long-range goals and objectives into specific, prioritised and executable tasks which you must do daily, weekly, monthly, quarterly, and even annually. GOALS, PRIORITIES, and a PLAN, set your direction and direct your focus on the things that matter to you the most. In a nut shell, GOALS, PRIORITIES and a PLAN, give your the reasons for getting out of bed quickly every morning, and for staying - and feeling - alive. To use a military analogy, GOALS, PRIORITIES and a PLAN, are like precise commands preset into the flight plan of a Tomahawk missile, homing on to a predefined long-distance target. All the strategic and tactical initiatives, as laid out in your systematic game plan, will embody the envisaged vivid image of your ultimate success achievement, which you are likely to hold in your head, thus serving as your personal driving force, keeping you inspired, motivated and focused, in the hot pursuit of your desired outcomes or cherished dreams. I have already written extensively about goal setting and goal achieving, including how to set up an systematic game plan on Quora. You can search their archives. 2) At the microcosmic level, I suggest that you to learn, acquire and practise proven efficient and effective study tools like SQ5R and Cornell Notes. i) SQ5R reading/studying strategy: It's a structured system [SQ5R is an acronym for SURVEY, QUESTIONS, READ, RECORD, RECITE, REVIEW, REFLECT], but it equips you with efficient and effective ways to flesh out key ideas and salient points quickly and systematically, thus helping you to navigate academic materials, especially the intellectually-intense ones, with ease, expediency and ace. I append herewith a nice write-up on SQ5R for your kind perusal: http://www.saddleback.edu/upload... ii) Cornell Notes: It's a far more superior system that the conventional outline method, known to most students in schools, college and universities. It's latent power comes from its simple and yet elegant three-column spatial configuration for taking notes and making notes. The "cue" column is the most powerful system I have ever known, as it facilitates - and expedites - your memory retention/recall via self-testing. You may want to read this nice write-up on Cornell Notes method of note-taking and note-making, in conjunction with SQ5R reading strategy: Guide to Effective Note Taking - SQ3R and Cornell - The Student Power This intellectually stimulating website belongs to fellow Quoran Joao Ramos. 3) Study the nature and structure of each of your academic subjects to determine their significance, i.e. understanding why you are studying them, and why they are important to you, in relationship to your future employability and career tracking. Remember what Leonardo da Vinci had exhorted more than five hundred years ago: "Everything connects to everything else!" Once you have this forward-looking gestalt perspective, your studying becomes a total breeze for you; 4) In conjunction with (2) and (3), you may want to explore the use of the seemingly popular and yet proven effective productivity tools: (i) The Eisenhower Method of time management (ii) Productivity 101: A Primer to The Pomodoro Technique; (iii) Jerry Seinfeld's Productivity Secret; You may also want to consider this practice: If something crosses your mind while your studying or working at home, and it continues to bug you, just make a quick note of that "something" and record it in a notebook, which you may want to designate as "Distractions Notebook." This initiative helps to get that "something" out of your system. To me, it's excellent way to do a brain dump, so that you have a de-cluttered mind to do the more important stuff. As soon as you have done this, move on with what you have been focusing on. When you are free, then only you can decide whether you want to address those "distractions" in your brain dump. Oftentimes, most of them will die out on their own, without your intervention at all. According to Dr Deepak Chopra, about 70,000 thoughts run through our mind in a given day. He even says about 95% of those thoughts are the same as yesterday's. 5) Before you proceed to study/revise each academic subject, learn to categorise them into: (i) concept-based/memory-dependent, like Biology, History, Geography, etc ; [In Singapore, we call them "mugging" subjects, as one needs to "mug up" in order to master them, as there are helluva lot of stuff to remember.] (ii) problem-solving, like Math, Physics, etc.; (iii) interpretation/prediction based, e.g. English Literature; Nonetheless, some subjects may straddle more than one category, e.g. Physics, and Chemistry, which have a lot of problem solving elements, notwithstanding lab experiments; To study them, do a mix-up during lesson revision and rehearsal at home, and also to allow you to be more energy-efficient, particularly in using 25-minute revising/5-minute break over a 2-hour stretch, thus attaining more 'Primacy' and 'Recency Effects'. 6) Preview your new lesson the night before class, by preparing preliminary notes. This is because, when you are learning something new in class, your prior knowledge will always come into play to make connections and create linkages. Learning psychologists call this phenomenon, "schema activation". More schema, more understanding! 7) Make sure that you thoroughly understand the content of all your class lectures; if not, you have to ask for clarification or elucidation from your lecturers or professors. To me, the acid test for understanding something new is your ability to explain the new concept to someone else, like your kid brother or even your grandma. No puns intended; 8) At the end of a class lecture, always do a quick Recap, Review and Reinforce, preferably with mnemonics - I call this the 3R's strategy. Science says about 80% of your information intake is lost if you do not execute this initiative within 24 hours; 9) At least for every semester quarter, or a couple of weeks prior to your final test/exam time, spend time and effort to prepare global consolidated and summarised study notes, as part of your final test/exam prep, by incorporating: - preliminary notes from your textbook reading, the night before class; - notes taken and made during the lecture; - notes taken and made from lecture handouts, if any; - notes taken and made from class discussions or group-work, if any; - notes from lab reports and/or field work; - other notes, e.g. from research at the library, or from the Internet search; 10) Also, with the aid of your subject syllabus as well as exam syllabus, learn to identify and segregate "core material" from "elaborative material". - "core material" = important concepts, principles, theories, definitions, terminologies, nomenclatures, important diagrams or graphs, etc.; - "elaborative material" = illustrations, examples, anecdotes, etc.; Drawing on Pareto's Law: About 80% of your exam questions are likely to come from your "core material", and so you know what and where to focus first. This is not to say "elaborative material" is not important, but once you have the intellectual grasp of "core material" in the first instance, "elaborative material" will naturally falls into place - in your memory banks; Transcribe "core material" into 4x3 index cards for their pocket portability, using the proven Index Card Strategy, for "learning-on-the-go": commuting and/or waiting in queue, as this facilitates random self-quizzing; 11) Review your learned class lesson within 24 hours, and then prepare a systematic spaced and distributed practice of revision/rehearsal, next 7 days/ next 30 days/next 60 days/ next 90 days/ next 180 days, till test/exam time; This initiative helps you to beat or circumvent the deadly impact of the infamous Ebbinghaus Effect, or better known as the Forgetting Curve; 12) Master the 100+ Test Verbs, often used by examiners in test/exam questions; 13) Always remember [I hate to say this, but it's a harsh reality], tests/exams are a form of game, and you got to learn to be an excellent game player. First of all, a test/exam is always a game of PRECISION and SPEED. No matter how you look at it, examiners are only interested in your ability to answer questions PRECISELY and EXPEDIENTLY, all within the prescribed time limits. So, to beat them in the game, you got to learn to master the technique of doing a "surgical cut" of the exam questions at first glance, no matter how they are phrased. That's why (12) is critical here. For your strategy to win the game, learn and practice the Question Dissection Protocol (*), a powerful technique for dissecting test/exam questions, developed by award-winning educator Doug Buehl from Madison, Wisconsin; I have already written extensively about this technique on Quora. You can search their archives. 14) Spend time and make concerted effort to tackle the past exam series, under simulated test/exam conditions; 15) If you are familiar with the graphical methods of note-taking and note-making, like idea-mapping, cluster diagramming and/or graphic organising, apply what I call a 'Divide and Conquer' strategy by creating a global idea map for each of your subject matter, using the tapestry of contents of your textbook as branching ideas; alternatively, you can also use the core ideas captured in (7); 16) I have in fact written an extended piece on lesson revision and rehearsal as a prelude to final test/exam preparation, originally intended for high-school/junior college students in Singapore, entitled: THE ART & DISCIPLINE OF REVISION STRATEGY You should read it. Here's the link: Say Keng Lee's post in OPTIMUM PERFORMANCE TECHNOLOGIES 17) Last but not least, especially if you are interested, acquire a copy of Adam Robinson's 'What Smart Students Know' and Ronald Gross' 'Peak Learning', and do your best to read as well as digest them. Definitely, you will be amply rewarded! So, my end analysis: it is not studying harder, but learning smarter, with the right strategy you are likely to utilize purposefully, meaningfully and productively within academic goal. I take this chance to wish you a pleasant and effective educational trip, and can even all fondest desires be realized. [20160312_Smart Learn tips]
